description: '''''Yé-yé''''' ({{IPA|fr|jeje|lang|LL-Q150 (fra)-WikiLucas00-yé-yé.wav}}) or '''''yeyé''''' ({{IPA|es|ɟʝeˈʝe|lang}}) was a style of pop music that emerged in [[Western Europe|Western]] and [[Southern Europe]] in the early 1960s. The French term ''yé-yé'' was derived from the English "yeah! yeah!", popularized by British [[beat music]] bands such as [[the Beatles]]. The style expanded worldwide as the result of the success of figures such as French singer-songwriters [[Sylvie Vartan]], [[Serge Gainsbourg]] and [[Françoise Hardy]]. Yé-yé was a particular form of [[counterculture]] that derived most of its inspiration from British and American [[rock and roll]]. Additional stylistic elements of ''yé-yé'' song composition include baroque, exotica, pop, jazz and the French ''[[chanson]].''
